metadata.title: Data-driven occupancy profile identification and application to the ventilation schedule in a school building
metadata.description: Facing the current sustainability challenges requires reduction in building stock energy usage towards achieving the European Green Deal targets. This can be accomplished by adopting techniques such as fault detection and diagnosis and efficiency optimization. Taking an Estonian school as a case study, an occupancy-based algorithm for scheduling ventilation operations in buildings is here developed starting only from energy use data. The aim is optimizing the system’s operation according to occupancy profiles while maintaining a comfortable indoor climate. By relying only on electricity meters without using carbon dioxide or occupancy sensors, we use the historical data of a school to develop a DBSCAN-based clustering algorithm that generates consumption profiles. A novel occupancy estimation algorithm, based on threshold and time-series methods, then creates 12 occupancy schedules that are either based on classical detection with an on-off method or on occupancy estimation for demand-controlled ventilation. We find that the latter replaces the 60% capacity of current on-off schedules by 30% or even 0%, with energy savings ranging from 3.5% to 66.4%. The corresponding costs are reduced from 18.1% up to 62.6%, while still complying with current national regulations for indoor air quality. Remarkably, our method can immediately be extended to other countries, as it relies only on occupancy schedules that ignore weather and other location-specific factors.

metadata.title: Variation of the Springtime Western Boundary Current in the Bay of Bengal (1993–2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset is developed using a velocity-based percentile threshold technique to identify the Western Boundary Current (WBC) region in the Bay of Bengal (BoB; 4°N–24°N, 76°E–100°E). The basis velocity field is from the Ocean Reanalysis System 5 (ORAS5; Zuo et al., 2019) from 1993 to 2020.

The BoB experiences seasonally reversing monsoon winds that drive the seasonally reversing boundary current system along the eastern coast of India (i.e., the western boundary of the BoB). The WBC in the BoB flows northward during the spring season (March–May). We present the results of an objective detection approach to separate the WBC from the rest of the flow using a combination of statistics and clustering.

In the WBC region, the alongshore currents increase rapidly and non-linearly toward the jet core across the current's width, producing sharp spatial gradients that dynamically distinguish the WBC from the surrounding flow (Stommel, 1962; Halkin and Rossby, 1985; Pierini et al., 2011; Beron-Vera et al., 2020). To isolate the WBC from the surrounding flow, a percentile-based threshold of current magnitude was applied for each WBC month (March, April, and May) during 1993–2020 (Gupta et al., 2025). Despite this thresholding, scattered spurious points remained, which were then removed using DBSCAN (Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise) (Ester et al., 1996). The outcome of this detection procedure is illustrated through one Video (MP4 file) and 28 Figures (PNG files), where the first row displays the complete current field, and the second row highlights the detected WBC. The color shading represents the current magnitude, with vectors representing its direction.

On visually inspecting the mapped WBC, the interannual variability in the current can be observed. For most of the time, the current magnitudes are the highest in April, followed by March and May, suggesting that the WBC begins to form in March, matures in April, and starts to decay in May. Interannually, the WBC generally shows enhanced strength during El Niño-associated years and reduced strength during La Niña-associated years. Moreover, the increased strength during El Niño results in more meandering than La Niña. 

This dataset has been developed on the motivation from our earlier work, Gangopadhyay et al., 2013, and a forthcoming publication, Gupta et al., 2025.

metadata.title: Supplementary Materials for "Unsupervised learning and statistical analysis of wind–solar complementarity in Vlora, Albania
metadata.description: This repository contains the supplementary materials accompanying the manuscript “Unsupervised learning and statistical analysis of wind–solar complementarity in Vlora, Albania.” It includes ERA5-based data preprocessing, statistical indices, clustering validation, and sensitivity analyses (S1–S5), along with the code notebook and metadata for reproducibility.

metadata.title: Federated Learning for Time-Series Clustering in Healthcare: A Privacy-Preserving Framework for Patient Risk Analysis Improvement
metadata.description: This dissertation proposes a federated learning framework for collaborative healthcare data analysis without centralising sensitive patient information. A fuzzy time-series clustering approach was developed to analyse continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) data across multiple institutions, integrating differential privacy and client subsampling to enhance confidentiality. Experiments demonstrated stable clustering performance under varying privacy settings, supporting the potential of federated fuzzy learning for secure, scalable medical data analytics under GDPR and HIPAA compliance.

For further (already published) data, see Gerstmeier (2018, 2019). This concerns the “species” Eucymatodera sp. 1 till Eucymatodera sp. 3., all paratypes, here.

Diagnosis. Head and pronotum with conspicuous punctation.Antennae more-or-less reaching base of pronotum (when laid back), antennomeres dilated from A5 onwards, longer than wide. Elytral base margined, punctation with a basal seta. Prosternal length more-or-less like procoxal diameter. AMP not rectangular, bulging only in front. Gular pads large, separated or adjoined.

Description. Length: 4.5–9.9 mm.

Head black, with dense, conspicuous punctation; labrum slightly and broadly emarginate or broadly rounded; clypeus with coarse punctation (diameter larger than punctation on head), not emarginate. Antennae more-or-less reaching base of pronotum (when laid back), antennomeres dilated from A5 onwards, longer than wide, A11 conspicuously shorter than A9+A10, not bulbous, more-or-less narrow, only very slightly constricted towards tip.

EyW: 0.16–0.38 mm; EyD: 0.52–1.06 mm; EyD/EyW: 2.78.

Pronotum black, subparallel in front, conspicuously constricted towards base, slightly sinuate before middle; with dense, conspicuous, more-or-less deep punctation.

PL: 1.04–2.36 mm; PW: 0.8–1.7 mm; PL/PW: 1.35.

Elytra totally black or with an orange (yellow-brown) transverse fascia (sometimes double banded) or an orange fascia more-or-less triangularly extended towards base (but far away from scutellum) and narrowly along the suture towards apex, apex broadly orange. Elytral base margined, elytra subparallel, slightly to conspicuously dilated towards apex. Punctation in 10 rows, extending beyond the middle, diameter of punctation conspicuously smaller than interstices, becoming smaller behind the orange transverse fascia, disappearing at apex or becoming irregular; punctation with a basal seta; interstices with microsculpture.

EL: 3.04–6.92 mm; EW: 1.36–3.21 mm; EL/EW: 2.19.

Legs yellow-brown to red-brown (or dark brown), tibial base sometimes darkened.

Lower surface. Head and thorax dark brown to black brown, abdomen yellow-brown to red-brown. Gula transversely wrinkled or smooth (in one case), gular pads large, separated or adjoined. Prosternal length more-or-less like procoxal diameter. AMP not rectangular, bulging only in front. Mesoventrite very coarsely, deeply (with variable diameter) and densely punctate. Metaventrite finely and diffusely punctate.

Genitalia. See Fig. 25. Same genitalia in all variations.

Distribution: Namibia, Republic of South Africa.

Etymology. In honor of my friends Doris, Ralf († 2024) and Jochen Schindler, who have always given me a warm welcome and extensive support during all my trips to Namibia.

metadata.title: A Review of Anomaly Detection Machine Learning and Deep Learning Techniques
metadata.description: Abstract: In general, an anomaly may be defined as a variance or departure from what is expected or normal. According to historical records, the term "anomaly" was derived from the Greek word "anomalia," which translates as "uneven" or "irregular." Many examples of such abnormalities or deviations from normalcy have occurred in our everyday lives, and we have all seen them. For example, when a condition monitoring system detects any value or parameter of the machine that falls outside the minimum value limit to the maximum value limit, it beeps an alert. Similarly, when credit card fraud is detected, it notifies both the bank and the customer immediately. Currently, the most challenging problem is determining how to identify irregularities in data streams. An example of a data stream is a continuous stream of data that is continuously formed from any source and is referred to as streaming data (also known as streaming information). Finding anomalies in such a significant amount of data will be a time-consuming and challenging endeavour. In this paper, we will delve into the details of data streams and anomaly detection in data streams, examining a substantial number of papers and articles published on the topic in recent years.

metadata.title: GPS-Based Bus Stop Prediction Using Machine  Learning: A Data-Driven Approach for Smart  Urban Transit
metadata.description:
Abstract - Urbanization and increased reliance on public transport warrants efficient bus stop identifying. This research utilizedmachine learning and DBSCAN clustering to predict bus stops from GPS traces (GPX files) identifying true stops versus 
temporary stops. Key steps included preforming preprocessing of GPX data (latitude, longitude, speed, timestamp), detecting 
zero-speed periods, and clustering stop points based on frequency and confidence. The model for predicting bus stops scores GPX files for support and frequency of stops that occur in a particular GPX file. The resulting system tested against OpenStreetMap (OSM) data and manual surveys accurately identified bus stopsin a variety of urban settings, including urban settings with density and complexity. Utilization of interactive maps and statistical visualizations supported better interpretation of identified bus stops, and the overall approach is easily scalable for transit agencies to better plan transit in their context and 
hopefully improve passenger experience across cities and contexts.
keywords: Urbanization, Public Transport, Bus Stop Prediction, GPS Traces, GPX Files, Machine Learning, DBSCAN Clustering, Preprocessing, Zero-Speed Detection, Clustering, Stop Frequency, Confidence Scoring, OpenStreetMap, Manual Survey, Urban Mobility, Interactive Maps, Statistical Visualization, Transit Planning, Passenger Experience, Scalability

metadata.title: Climate reanalysis data and hazard masks for DBSCAN clustering - Veneto Region (2018-2022)
metadata.description: This dataset contains the input climate data needed to execute the DBSCAN clustering code (jupyter notebook) for the identification of multi-hazard spatial and temporal footprints in the Veneto Region. This dataset is to be used only for testing the code. The publication with the results of the complete analyses is in preparation and will cover 1991-2022 for historical scenario and 2023-2070 for future scenarios (RCP 4.5 and RCP 8.5).

creators.name: Ferrario, Davide Mauro
creators.affiliation: Istituto Universitario di Studi Superiori di Pavia
